title: Business Live: Just Eat shares pop on counter bid
text:
Science Photo Library Copyright: Science Photo Library

As if there weren't enough trade tensions in the world already, now India and Malaysia are squaring up for a fight.

Malaysia is the second-biggest producer and exporter of palm oil, while India is its biggest buyer. But India's top vegetable oil trade body has called on its members to boycott Malaysian palm oil because of a political row over Indian-administered Kashmir.

Back in August, the Indian government revoked part of the constitution that gave Kashmir special status. Then last month, Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said India had "invaded and occupied" the Muslim-majority region.

Dr Mahathir says he is standing by his comments, but he will look into the issue.

He said: "This is not the Indian government, so we have to find out how we can communicate with these people, because trade is a two-way thing and it is bad to have what amounts to a trade war."

The Indian government has declined to comment on the trade dispute, but says its actions in Kashmir are an internal matter.
